heading: From the Emerald Isle to the Brass City
paragraphs: By the twentieth century, millions of Irish were forced to leave the ancient places of their surnames' origins due to centuries of political and economic upheavals.
First to land in Waterbury is Martin John Kerwin. He married his wife, Elizabeth Bergin, the summer before, while living in Naugatuck, Connecticut.

images.alt: A scanned photograph of a brick factory along a set of railroad tracks
An abandoned brick factory along a set of railroad tracks

paragraphs: A gritty industrial city of approximately 100,000, situated at the Naugatuck and Mad Rivers in central Connecticut, Waterbury had been the center of the American brass industry since the early 19th century.

Michael Joseph Kerwin and his brother, John, emigrated from Queenâ€™s County, Ireland, to New York, New York, in June 1907. They would end up in Waterbury, Connecticut, where their half-brother, Martin, had been living for the past six years.
The brothers noted that their purpose for emigration was to join Martin, who even paid for their passage.
